name: overexpose
content:
overexpose verb [T usually passive]
(EXPERIENCE)
Add to word list
Add to word list
to make someone or something experience something too much, or for too long, risking harm: He is another employee who was regularly overexposed to lead, arsenic, and cadmium in his 26 years at the plant.
More examplesFewer examplesThe new insecticides were also widely used in farming, and the mosquitoes that had been overexposed quickly became resistant to the chemicals.The staining of teeth is a warning sign that the child has been overexposed to fluoride.People retire to southern climes and overexpose their skin.

overexpose verb [T usually passive]
(ATTENTION)
to give too much attention to someone or something in newspapers, on television, on social media, etc.: His parents and his team protected him from being overexposed, keeping him from doing interviews and turning down endorsement deals.
More examplesFewer examplesSome media watchers say the comedian risks becoming the kind of overexposed personality he so mercilessly mocks.Unlike some actresses, Miss Shue has never been overexposed.Topping the charts can make a career, of course, but it can also overexpose the performer and create a backlash.

overexpose verb [T usually passive]
(PHOTOGRAPH)
to give too much light to a piece of photographic film when taking a photograph: Unfortunately the light was too bright and my pictures were all overexposed. Since my camera allows me to preset exposure above and below the automatic reading, I typically overexpose my shots by one f-stop.
